text: Agreed. They're a business, they made whatever business decision they made, I accept that. But they can't do that and then at the same time claim credit for feeling really bad about it and some vague "we need to find ways to make voices heard" blather.
author: poniewozik

text: The thing is, I'm fine with accepting that it's a business and their call. But by that token, they can't simultaneously plead for some sort of special "But we tried really hard!" sympathy. Corporations aren't people!
author: poniewozik

text: Right: there are a bunch of difficult-to-measure factors involved in these decisions, which is why I assume, algorithm or no, the calculation is more art than science.
author: poniewozik

text: Also, just to be a crank about this again, this is why "Give us the numbers for ODAAT" doesn't do much. Suppose Netflix says, "Ah, you see, it only had 55,000 Granfaloons." Unless you have the *same* numbers for *most or all* of their shows, there's nothing to compare it to.
author: poniewozik

text: I mean, that last point isn't a nefarious plot--it is more expensive to buy a show from an outside producer! But it's just a far less clean calculation than where you can say, "These ratings get us $X for a 30-second ad" (tho even at the networks it's more complicated now).
author: poniewozik

text: But also, even if they gave a precise, credible number of viewers, we wouldn't know 1) how that compares to their other shows 2) what the calculus is re ODAAT driving subscriptions (since there's no ads) and 3) the overall cost calc for the show (esp since they buy it from Sony)
author: poniewozik

text: Put another way, I'm willing to agree there is, in fact, an "enough" point. Otherwise, they'd make everything and keep it all on forever. But 1) it is a far more nebulous calculation than for ad-supported TV and 2) we have no data on it.
author: poniewozik

text: I don't tend to believe that TV outlets/networks make great shows just for the twisted pleasure of cancelling them. But sometimes they work harder to keep shows alive than others. Without any numbers as a basis, there's no way of assessing or comparing this for streaming outlets.
author: poniewozik

text: The logical conclusion of that, tho, is that low viewership is *never* a reason to cancel a streaming show. Streamers, like pay cable, make a different, vague calculus of how much a show contributes to subscriptions. But bc Netflix gives no numbers, we can't judge/compare.
author: poniewozik

text: But remember everybody, 85 gajillion people watched that one show that Netflix shared some kind of number for that one time!
author: poniewozik

text: Add to this that we don't know the cost for Netflix to take ODAAT from an outside studio, vs a show it produced itself. "Not enough people watched" always = "This show wasn't making us enough $ to be worth it to us," but it's even harder than usual to assess what "enough" was.
author: poniewozik

text: If the Oscars wants to exclude a group in order to preserve a business & cultural norm they deem valuable, fine--but to me as a critic, once you do that, you can't claim you're making a critical judgment, i.e., defining an aesthetic category and honoring the best in it.
author: poniewozik

text: Likewise, if the Oscars are basically a trade-group ritual designed to reward and enforce their preferred practice/standards in their field, that's their business. It's only to the extent that they present themselves as an act of aesthetic gatekeeping that I care.
author: poniewozik

text: Any awards body can have whatever criteria it wants. As a critic, I only care to the extent they purport to define aesthetic categories. If the Peabody's purview is "The best of whatever happened to be delivered to televisions," fine--it doesn't affect my definition of what's TV.

text: I mean the Oscars can do whatever they want. They can say it’s not a movie if you can’t buy popcorn at it. That doesn’t make it a legit aesthetic distinction, which is all I’m concerned about as a critic.

text: Whatever Cohen's checks prove legally, his bringing them is a striking visual, which is a very Trump move. Trump's go-to is displaying objects--manila folders, "Trump steaks"--knowing that the imagery of the thing is more powerful than the thing itself.

text: Re whether Trump "directed" Cohen: it's important for journalists to report on whether it met the legal standard. But that's not the only issue: there's also using the common sense God gave us. Weirdly, we've developed this idea that not doing so makes us "credible."

text: Agreed--lifting verbatim text is just clear-cut plagiarism, regardless if there's a note.
author: poniewozik

text: ...so if the idea is that this sort of endnote citation is deceptive wherever it's used, then I'd expect to see takedowns of thousands of books currently published. (In any case, tho, it's her lifting chunks of text w/o quotes that's the bigger offense.)
author: poniewozik

text: In this case "cite" would be an endnote keyed to a quote in the text, which is the widespread practice in nonacademic nonfiction books. (The other, worse, common option being no notes at all, or a vague "bibliography.") I've got a stack of recent books that use the same system.
author: poniewozik

text: Yeah, it sounds like deflecting, because it's actually not the major offense that she needs to address (and hasn't explained).
author: poniewozik

text: (But it's also a different issue altogether from flat-out lifting big chunks of text unquoted or unattributed, which is the much bigger offense she's been caught out for.)
author: poniewozik

text: That's actually an argument I sort of agree with, at least if she's talking about references that she's already cited in an endnote. I wouldn't want to read a nonfiction book where every note citation is doubled up with an "in an interview with..." line in the text.
author: poniewozik

text: One thing that throws me about the interview is where he seems to say it's "problematic" to cite a source but not do it in the body of the text--which would suggest that endnotes themselves are inherently deceptive. But it may just be the syntax of the question throwing me off.
author: poniewozik

text: I would totally subscribe to the argument that Suck perfected the form.
author: poniewozik

text: Another thing abt the Abramson book: people have focused on its dismissiveness of Vice & BF; but there's also a lot of unexamined traditionalism in how she writes about the NYT & the WaPo. A lot of "it used to be this way" reverence, not so much "this new way is better."
author: poniewozik

text: Useful thing about this interview is it details the problem: chunks of text that are mostly verbatim--yet changed *enough* that it was clearly not simply cut-and-paste. Frustrating thing is she won't/can't just explain how that happened.

text: Where and what year? He spoke at my wife's graduation at U-M (1991, the year after I graduated), and I saw that one too--it was his speech that decried "political correctness," and it ended up being big national news.
author: poniewozik

text: Which again, is the explanation I've always heard for why trade publishers prefer endnotes keyed to text--only the (few) readers who care see them. So it's funny to see it treated like, "Why are they hiding the citations!!!"
author: poniewozik

text: Yeah, honestly, before the last 24 hours I had never even encountered the idea that endnotes are some sneaky way to bamboozle readers into thinking you didn't use secondary sources. (If JA lifted chunks of verbatim prose w/o quoting, that's another issue & obvs plagiarism.)
author: poniewozik

text: Agree.
author: poniewozik

text: I'm using notes keyed to text in my own book because it's my publisher's house style, so it was the only choice. I feel like I don't generally see note markers in text much outside academic writing--certainly not often in trade nonfiction.
author: poniewozik

text: It's interesting to see this discussion; in my experience, endnotes keyed to text (vs marked in superscript &c) are used at *publisher's* request for trade books--the thinking being that readers find note markers distracting. In general, it seems to be this or no notes at all.

text: And maybe the answer is, "Well, we don't know, but how do we know any ratings are accurate?" Then we're just at: OK, all data is a form of fiction, believe what you want! Which may be the case, but then that would be an argument against covering... any of it.
author: poniewozik

text: I feel I must be saying this poorly, but: tell me three shows that You on Netflix has a bigger audience than. (Anywhere, Netflix, cable, other streaming, whatever.) Tell me three that it has a smaller audience than. How do you know? What data is that based on?
author: poniewozik

text: What is a number that you put out *for one show* useful for? If it is, as you say, just to assure creatives, *that is still just a form of spin*! It's not even apples-to-apples for their own product. It's just getting a large number into excited circulation.
author: poniewozik

text: If the reports are correct, this will be the third straight SOTU / Address to Congress in which Trump invited relatives of murder victims to send the message that immigrants are a deadly danger and we should be afraid of them. But, you know, unity.
author: poniewozik

text: I'm just saying that ratings are useful insofar as they enable you to compare one thing to another thing. I'd love it if we had that for Netflix. And if we did, they might well be huge numbers! But this ain't it.
author: poniewozik

text: OK. Based on that, what shows is You larger and smaller than? What show has a larger audience than 40M of [that specific metric]? What show has a smaller one--Netflix or linear TV or otherwise? If we don't know, *what does the 40M figure tell us*?
author: poniewozik

text:
I think we can recognize simultaneously:
-Netflix is obvs a big phenomenon
-Networks always BS about ratings
-This stat was a new version of old BS
-We nonetheless should always point out BS as BS
author: poniewozik

text: BTW, I do not doubt at all that You got a huge profile from going on Netflix. But I think we can say that and at the same time recognize that that 40M number can't be compared to the same figure for... any other TV show. So it's not a relative measure of anything.
author: poniewozik

text: That's exactly the thing, you can't compare it--because that metric is not applied to any of those shows. It doesn't mean that the series is 10x as watched as a TV show w 4 million people in the ratings. It's not the same metric. But clearly a lot of people inferred it was.
author: poniewozik

text: (None of this, BTW, is meant to challenge your point about his citing SVOD numbers, which I trust you're right about!)
author: poniewozik

text: Assuming that their count of 40 million--whatevers!--is 100% honest and legit, what did it mean? What show can we confidently say, based on that number, You on Netflix was more or less viewed than? Nothing, AFAIK. So it's just an effort to get a large number into stories.
author: poniewozik

text:
I still think Landgraf has more the right of it. 
40M, even if truthful by the stated metric, is a useless number if you can't say, "compared to what?"
One doesn't need to lie to mislead. Throwing out a big useless number does mislead--even if, you're right to say, others do it.

text: Also anecdotally, I don't feel like I'm seeing "Wow, this is big!" reactions to Sex Education, which IIRC Netflix reported *the same number* for? (Making it the only direct comparison I know of?) Maybe because there was no Nielsen # to to-be-sure-this-is-not-a-direct-comparison.
author: poniewozik

text: I mean, I still remember a hundred million years ago when the narrative was that the second run on Netflix *benefitted* shows like Breaking Bad and Sons of Anarchy.
author: poniewozik

text: Though, again, it would be more fruitful to examine that if we had numbers to make the same comparison for Riverdale, or a whole universe of other shows Netflix has streaming rights for.
author: poniewozik

text: I mean, Stranger Things was able to do that without (IIRC) the benefit of any numbers. Which seemed perfectly legit. I have no issue with recognizing that certain Netflix shows have cultural reach, it's just the loose use of numbers that gets my ratings-nerd hackles up.
author: poniewozik

text: It would be useful even to be able to compare the figures for Netflix shows with the same figures for *other Netflix shows*. Since we can't, I'm just cautious about overinterpreting. Which doesn't mean one can't just write about You because it's interesting / talked about!
author: poniewozik

text: Very good point--cultural reach is hard to really measure for a lot of things! Which is why IMHO it just makes sense to say both 1) "This seems big" and 2) "We don't really have the information or context to say how big, compared with other big things."
author: poniewozik

text: Like, yeah, eventually you get to the "Who knows what this all means," but given how people process information, if you're implicitly inviting them to draw a comparison--they'll draw it!
author: poniewozik

text: What I see a lot of is pieces like this which eventually say, "To be sure, these numbers aren't directly comparable to Nielsen ratings..." but first, they directly juxtapose the numbers with the linear Lifetime rating.
author: poniewozik

text: Yeah, to be clear, I didn't mean to say you were making that argument, but I have been seeing direct comparisons of Netflix figs vs Nielsens elsewhere. IMHO Netflix's reach is clearly "big" & important, & also we don't yet have many means of comparing how big w/r/t other media.
author: poniewozik

text: So, given that a "big" rating is always a relative term, it has to be relative to *the same metric* applied to a different show. For Netflix's shows, that doesn't exist--we can't just pull up old Nielsens and say, "40 million, clearly You is bigger than American Idol."
author: poniewozik

text: Assuming they're equally trustworthy/suspicious, it's not apples-to-apples. Nielsen is telling you how many people watched a show on a night (or over 3 days, or...) not how many watched X% of at least one episode of a full season.
author: poniewozik

text: To return to the Friends comparison, one thing we don't know is how big Friends' audience would have been if you applied the same metrics as Netflix's 40 million comes from. Would it be 100 million? 200? Without that knowledge, this kind of comparison is specious.
author: poniewozik

text: Like, if we found out that 40 million people watched The Masked Singer last night, we would have an immediate apples-to-apples sense of its size & reach compared with TV shows of the past.
author: poniewozik

text: What Adam said. The number in itself sounds big, and for all I know may be big, but there isn't the detail or context to say how big--and especially not enough to compare it with a linear TV show with 40 million Nielsen viewers. (Which is more than American Idol at its peak!)
author: poniewozik

text:
And to your later point, I too am REALLY averse to people writing this up as "40 million people watched You! It's as big as Friends!" Because... we don't know that? 
And yet, it's so APPEALING to make that claim, bc come on, which thing are more people going to read?
author: poniewozik

text: ...and Netflix's numbers, as you say, aren't really useful for either. But these kind of metrics could be useful for the latter, if you had detailed, contextualized figures, preferably measured by a disinterested third party.
author: poniewozik

text: Put another way, ratings are useful for measuring more than just business success--the problem is when people use a metric for one thing (how much money can this show make?) for another purpose (how much has this show penetrated the culture?)
author: poniewozik

text: Any TV viewing measure is 'useful' in relation to what it's trying to measure. So one kind of rating is useful for determining ad $ rates, another for determining total cultural reach. So Netflix #s COULD be useful to gauge cultural reach--problem is we don't know what they mean.
author: poniewozik

text: That's always tough to say in the present, but it feels more of its moment than (to take the obvi comparison) 30 Rock, as topical as that show was.

text: GoT is an interesting case for "What if No Sopranos," because the A Song of Ice and Fire books are in many ways the equivalent of the HBO approach in book-series form--and they began before The Sopranos. No reason they might not have become TV eventually regardless.

text: Sure, I'm not saying that without The Sopranos, nothing changes and we have exactly the same shows as we got. I am more skeptical of the idea, If not for The Sopranos, the TV-antihero era never happens, e.g.--as opposed to happening on a different timeline w different shows.

text: There I'd agree with you; where I'm skeptical is that it necessarily would have happened. I.e., it's not like HBO was destined to have a hit with whatever it put on the air in January 1999.
author: poniewozik

text: It broke into the original series business with Scandinavian Silvio! And that didn't catch on but the next thing did, as some next thing eventually will.

text: Yes, but I'm saying it's a show--by some people's lights the best drama of its era, or history--that didn't require Tony as an artistic antecedent, and in some sense reacted philosophically against him.
author: poniewozik

text: And The Corner (which HBO made after The Sopranos, but I imagine it would have made without The Sopranos?)
author: poniewozik

text: or maybe someone else makes an antihero show eventually and that becomes the Earth-2 Sopranos. The beauty of this, as I say, is it's all unprovable. But my bias in life is toward systemic factors over Great Man (or Great Show) Theory.
author: poniewozik

text: And I'm not sure The Wire needed The Sopranos as an antecedent; see Simon's point about how it was Greek as opposed to a Shakespearean approach to character. Now maybe HBO makes a different kind of show than Sopranos, it becomes the model & the viewing audience's tastes change 2/
author: poniewozik

text: I tend to believe the Butterfly Effect more in specific instances. Maybe Mad Men doesn't exist, because Weiner never gets The Sopranos on his resume. But OTOH, HBO's next drama was Six Feet Under; it could have been copied, but wasn't much. 1/

text: Yeah--I know I'm becoming a crank about this, and I don't doubt that Netflix is big and some shows get a massive boost on it and lotsa people watch Stranger Things or whatever, but without details they might as well be saying "Show X earned 75 million Granfalloons."
author: poniewozik

text: And assuming they are using *the same* figures for their other shows they give us. And assuming, LOL, that no one just types it up as "40M Netflix viewers watched You, which only got 600K viewers a week on Lifetime," because too good to check.
author: poniewozik

text: Combined with, "And it will get repeated without analysis, because that makes a more exciting story." (But I also mean that one shouldn't just assume that *any* figure reported by an interested party shouldn't just be assumed true.)
author: poniewozik

text: Yes, but lies, statistics, &c. Let's assume 40M viewers for You is 100% legit. The journalistic question is: "What does that mean, really?" What's a view? How much is it, compared to its Lifetime ratings? Compared to *wave hands generally* anything?
author: poniewozik

text: There's also honestly a viral media effect to cherrypicked viewer figures. It's a lot easier to pitch a story if you've got AHOOGA-AHOOGA numbers from the company to show an editor. Or just to create a general, ambient sense of "Wow, [show] is really huge now!"
author: poniewozik

text: So I wouldn't present it as "40 million households watched You," as I've been seeing. Or "40x more people watched it on Netflix than on Lifetime."
author: poniewozik

text: Maybe! *shrugs* That's kinda my point about the whole thing: assuming the numbers are 100% legit, you need to know what they're really measuring before you can compare apples to apples
author: poniewozik

text: I don't know how many different ways to say this, but as you know in TV ratings there are many ways to present technically "true" stats. Does "40 million households" watched = 4 million people watching 10 episodes, or...? At the least it begs for a "And what that means is..."
author: poniewozik

text: By "True with an asterisk," I'm saying that, in the world of ratings, something can be "true" but misleading. Are you counting one person watching a 10-episode show as 10 "viewers"? A three-second click as a "view"? These numbers can be used so many ways.
author: poniewozik

text: But just to be clear: 40 million households watching a TV show--without explanatory context--implies that it is more popular than any TV show since the height of the three-network era before cable. Which, if a Lifetime show did that, congrats! Or maybe there is further context!
author: poniewozik

text: In all seriousness, I'm not saying that streaming services' self-reported numbers are false. They may be 100% right! They may not. They may be true but cherrypicked. They may be true with an asterisk. We don't know--which is the point.
author: poniewozik

text: I’ve said this a lot lately, but journalists do, all the time, assess whether sources are credible enough to trust. It’s the job. In this case, the source lied on live TV on this subject twice in the last week. And you can cover a statement without airing it live and unfiltered.
author: poniewozik

text: Sure, maybe. But I would argue that news orgs should base their decisions not on trying to produce any political effect (or lack thereof)—but rather on doing the job of not letting their viewers be misinformed.

text: The actual Sopranos finale says, "What happens next is unknowable; there are endless possibilities." What the Tony Is Definitely Dead/Alive people want is a Bandersnatch-like assurance that there is one correct ending once you get to the end of that particular path.
author: poniewozik

text: Bandersnatch is about the idea that if you do Actions X and Y and go into a diner, then Action Z will always happen. It's knowable; you can put it on a flowchart. That's the certainty people want when they insist that you can "solve" the cut-to-black with one "right" answer.
author: poniewozik

text: In all seriousness, I do think that choose-your-path stories like Bandersnatch and the idea that there is one "right" answer to the Sopranos ending appeal to the same thing: the rejection of uncertainty & the idea that one set of actions always leads to the same knowable outcome.
author: poniewozik

author: poniewozik

text: For instance: Not a ton of critics included "America to Me," possibly my fave of the year. But there are a million things on TV, and I know only so many people saw it! I hope my writing made a couple more people watch, bc it's great, but I don't need it to "beat" anything else.
author: poniewozik

text: And this may just be a function of not taking lists very seriously, but I don't look at other lists and get mad my faves aren't on there. It's fine if you do! But I just don't see it as this Art Pokemon where my champions battle someone else's, and my worldview wins or loses.
author: poniewozik

text: The other question I won't answer is "Why did you put __ on the list," because the answer is in the list, and if it's insufficient for you, then we just disagree!
author: poniewozik

text: Also, one question I will never answer is "Why didn't you put ___ on your list?" The only answer is there were 10 shows I wanted to put on more. I never look at a show and think, "Hm, what are the reasons to leave this off?"--it may be other people's process but not mine.
author: poniewozik

text: The first thing I will say is that if you are tweeting at me to object to any inclusion or omission on my list, it is 99.99% likely you feel more strongly about my list than I do. Lists are fun, but being honest, if I made this list 30 different days I'd have 30 different lists.

text:
To me: It's "These are the top 10 shows and this is why *I* watch them." Often a good review/list makes me see why a critic likes something and why I wouldn't, & is interesting anyway. 

But maybe it *is* the implied message, which may be part of why I'm ambivalent about lists.

text: This is not a subtweet, btw. I suspect most critics feel the way I do, but I think a lot of people who *read* lists, and reviews, see it the opposite way. Maybe it's partly the DEBATE ME, COWARD culture of social media. Personally, if you like a thing I hate--I'm fine with that!

The more I think about it, the argument over whether to say "lie" in news is important but it's partly symbolic. 

The bigger issue is being able to treat people as dishonest/untrustworthy when they've proven themselves to be that way.

It's responsible to treat liars like liars.

text: I'm not familiar with TWD comics. But the show never seems to address that its philosophy isn't sustainable. If it's just tribal war of all against all, that ends up with everybody dead. TWD may think empathy is for suckers, but it's the only plan that has a chance long-term.
author: poniewozik

text:
TWD has two political-allegory messages, really: 
1) The zombies: The teeming horde is coming to overwhelm you and you have to band together with your own kind
2) The other survivor groups: You have to harden your heart, because every time you show empathy, you suffer for it.
author: poniewozik

text:

text: Yeah, 100%--I don't think one book can do everything and they can be complements.
author: poniewozik

text: Anyway, Woodward's thing has always been that you go to him for facts, not analysis--and obvs there is eye-opening stuff about the Trump circus in 'Fear.' I just there's *also* a value to a slightly tabloid-y approach to a tabloid presidency. /end /blahblahblah
author: poniewozik

text: But I do think you miss something about *what America is right now* if you decide that the culture war, media, TV, all that, is beneath the dignity of a serious presidential book. I don’t know if you can really capture Trump if you’re not willing to go beneath that dignity.
author: poniewozik

text: Clearly, Woodward has a sense of the proper subjects of a serious presidential book, and for him that’s matters like national security, diplomacy, institutional process, economic policy, war. Which is fine; different books can make different choices and complement each other.
author: poniewozik

text: There’s little about Trump’s culture warring in ‘Fear.’ His TV addiction, his Fox News symbiosis, is treated in passing. Charlottesville gets two chapters, but focused on the staff’s drama. Trump himself, his thoughts, motives, source of anger—it’s an enigma here, a black box.
author: poniewozik

text: Interesting Q about what Bob Woodward thought of Fire & Fury, which contrasts w 'Fear.' Journos were harder on F&F, and I can’t vouch for its reporting, but it had a sense of the spirit of the age—the shamelessness & craziness—that isn’t in BW's toolbox. http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2018/09/bob-woodward-interview-fear.html …

text: I'm not saying that it isn't newsworthy or noteworthy that the President is tweeting something insane--it is. But I don't think people are always conscious of how they help lies spread by RTing them uncorrected. (& again, I've been guilty myself.)
author: poniewozik

text: I don't expect it not to be RTed. I'm saying if you're RTing something you know to be false (esp journalists), the responsible thing is to include the truth at the same time. (As opposed to just a snarky comment, which I've been guilty of.)
author: poniewozik

text: There is a powerful, corrosive viral effect where Trump tweets something bogus, 1,000,000 people satisfiedly RT-dunk on him, and casual people see the retweet and get the idea that the basic facts are up for argument.
author: poniewozik

text: The Trump tweet everyone is RTing, denying, 3000 deaths in Puerto Rico, is wrong. Here's the story. I get the impulse to RT when the POTUS is tweeting something nuts, but don't just assume "everyone knows it's not true" when spreading his disinformation.

text: Fair. To me, what's more useful is, less, "There's enough here to check out" and more, "Here's what works and doesn't and why." That gives me a basis to figure if it's the kind of thing I--with my own subjective tastes like anyone--want to check out.
author: poniewozik

text: To put it less glibly: more often, the truth of a show is that it will be some people's thing and not others. There's no way of knowing which group an individual reader falls into, which is why, IMHO, "I liked it/hated it" is not the most interesting or useful part of a review.

text:
Reboot: old title, new cast, possibly new characters, setting, revised premise (Battlestar Galactica, One Day at a Time)
Revival: old title, same cast, what are they up to now? (Roseanne, Twin Peaks)
Remake: Same title & story, shot w new cast (kinda rare on TV?)

text: I literally said, in the very tweet that you’re responding to, that we did this even when we have ratings information. So I guess you got me, with exactly the point that I just made, good work
author: poniewozik

text: Exactly! In my experience editors overestimate the audience for shows like Mr. Robot or Mad Men because “everyone they know“ talks about them. That’s what happens even when you *do* have ratings. My point is this is exaggerated with streaming, because you have no ratings at all
author: poniewozik

text: Sorry, I mean it’s *not* something that I worry about when deciding what shows to review. But if you’re making a claim that something is a “hit,“ then having objective data matters, because the metrics of clicks or what your Twitter feed is talking about can be misleading
author: poniewozik

text: Again, this is an something that I’m worried about deciding about shows to review. But a lot of entertainment news and feature journalism is premised on, “this is a show with broad cultural reach and relevance,“ so it matters if that is based on mistaken idea of audience size
author: poniewozik

text: As a critic, I don’t care except out of curiosity about a show’s cultural reach. But it matters to the larger business of entertainment journalism, especially when it purports to reflect what people are interested in
author: poniewozik

text: I’m not saying that audience size is the only reason to cover a show! But we should keep in mind that the number of people talking about a thing on your Twitter feed does not necessarily reflect the world
author: poniewozik

text: Even when we have ratings information, media outlets often determine their coverage by “buzz.“ When it comes to streaming shows, buzz is essentially the only “metric” we have. (And it’s just as possible that we are underestimating audiences in some cases as overestimating.)
author: poniewozik

text: Not super surprised by this, but it’s another reason I really wish we had any credible independent figures on the audience for streaming shows

Trump likes words that mean whatever you want them to.

text:
But on what level do they buy in? Like:
-Trump gives an interview
-Trump says his DIRECT QUOTES are "fake news"
Do MAGA fans think it's *literally* fake, like "we faked the moon landing" fake?
Or like: "Yeah, he said it, but it hurts our side, so be loyal and ignore it"?

text: In that article, at least, the "you get prestige not money" line is directed toward the FT staff (copyeditors, &c), not writers--the piece doesn't really address how good or bad the writers' pay is, whether it's rich enough to compensate for lack of FT benefits or not, &c.
author: poniewozik

text: Agreed the title is misleading. Another question, I guess, is whether they're as relatively low-paid as the full-time staff are. (I mean, obviously companies don't generally go with contract employees to *increase* their costs.)
author: poniewozik

text: When I was at Time mag, at least, I was under the impression that Time Inc's practice of having magazine writers be actual full-time staff rather than on contract was the exception, rather than the rule, at glossy magazines. (Tho NYer calling them "staff writers" is misleading.)
author: poniewozik

text: Caveat that I don't know the NYer's specific arrangements, but isn't this a version of the (IIRC pretty widespread) magazine practice of having most writers on contract? (Tho they usually get referred to as "contributing editors" or similar, not "staff writers.")

text: This is probably a book in itself (and an oversimplification), but one big divide in America is between whether you judge goodness by 1) how good you treat neighbors and family vs 2) how you treat people you've never met.
author: poniewozik

text: Whatever you think of 'Roseanne' in particular, this is a real dynamic in American life worth exploring: the belief that as long as you're nice to the "good" people who are close to you, it mitigates how you treat larger groups in the abstract. 3/3
author: poniewozik

text: I also think the show is making a point that it may or may not intend to: the way people will be nice to people they know personally, yet still trash nameless larger groups in the abstract. (Cf how Dan talks about "illegals," whom we never meet.) 2/

text: There has to be independent empirical data to call something a hit. "I like it" or "Everyone I follow on Twitter is talking about it" or "The company that makes it says so" don't count.
author: poniewozik

text: (Oh, to your question: we don't have Nielsen figures on streaming though I believe they are moving into that area. If we had some sort of actual third-party data like that it would be a different story.)
author: poniewozik

text: I mean, "hit" has to have a specific meaning, like any term, or it doesn't mean anything. "Hit" implies popularity, and popularity implies numbers. Without data, it's just hype. There are other terms for "show I think is really good" or "shows generate a lot of thinkpieces," &c.
author: poniewozik

text: I've been seeing it with the renewal of Handmaid's Tale, which MAYBE is a hit? But also just as plausibly is a modestly watched show that's valuable to Hulu because it wins awards & elevates its profile. I don't know what I don't know, as the philosopher Megyn Kelly said.
author: poniewozik

text: (Sorry, I mean for NOT using "Everyone is talking about." It's fine to write about a show just because it's buzzy or interesting! But I avoid using terminology that implies "it's one of the most-watched shows on TV" if I don't know it to be true.)
author: poniewozik

text: Nielsen has its flaws, but it's far from a random sample. Election polls have far smaller samples--and while they make mistakes too, they're not just wild-ass guesses

text: This is not an issue limited to streaming, btw. I remember people in the media biz used to WILDLY overestimate how many people watched Mad Men, eg, bc everyone they know talked about it. But at least w a cable show you had data.

text: For non-Fox viewers, Trump had a weekly spot on F&F, "Mondays with Trump," from 2011 until he ran for president. People know how The Apprentice raised his profile, but Fox & Friends--half-politics, half entertainment--helped transition him from entertainer to politician.
author: poniewozik

text: To take another example: you could say that Trump is vain, dishonest and egocentric based on his long pre-political history as a public figure. But the way people speak about politics, a lot of people take that as a "liberal" position, bc we define politics in terms of antipathy.

text: Maybe what I'm saying is that *ideology* is different. Kanye complimenting Trump or Owens is a thing people can criticize; what throws me is the leap to his being "conservative" or "alt-right"--maybe he is, I don't know--based solely on these personal referents.
author: poniewozik

text: Yeah, didn't mean to make that sound like an argument. It's just something I wrestle with a lot because I'll write something about Trump's character or his TV presentation or whatever, and people will mention the "political" thing I wrote, and to me, there's no politics in it!

text: None of which is to defend Kanye or explain him; it's just weird--and utterly typical--that Kanye's "politics" are suddenly a given when I could not tell you, beyond a wild guess, what they actually are, if they even exist. 5/ThankGodItsFinallyOver
author: poniewozik

text: Being "liberal" means saying bad things about Trump. Being "conservative" means saying bad things about Obama. It's defined more by a person's stances toward the major agons than, like, what you think about political issues.
author: poniewozik

text: And maybe he's all of those things. I don't know! I'm not sure I could tell you his stance on a single issue. But his complimenting people who are political is "political," because we've defined politics as mainly about attitudes and affinities.
author: poniewozik

text: Nonetheless, the tweets become Kanye's "politics." He's conservative, or he's Trumpist, or he's, here, "alt-right."
author: poniewozik

text: Kanye has tweeted positive things about Trump, Candace Owens, Scott Adams. They, obviously, have had *definite* political opinions. But (maybe I've missed something), I can't think of a recent Kanye tweet that itself takes a specific position on a political issue.

author: poniewozik

text: I'm an outlier this way, but there have been times when, if you gave me the option to stream a certain movie the date of release at home, I'd have paid *more* for that than in the theater.
author: poniewozik

text: I would read that essay, because the arguments I usually see are nostalgia / Bowling Alone / aesthetics of the experience--i.e., the effect on the theatrical cinema *audience* rather than film as an art medium.
author: poniewozik

text: That actually is where I most agreed with Sam's argument, i.e., it's sad how minimally Netflix promoted 'Alone' (I felt like Mudbound got more push, maybe I'm wrong). But Netflix could do that--it certainly can do it for TV series when it chooses to.
author: poniewozik

text: You're not nuts, you're just advocating your interest! The best way, IMHO, to protect that interest is to get more people to genuinely share it, but there I do not have the answer.
author: poniewozik

text: It's been technologically available to us (and I'd have been glad to have it), but the existence of something like Netflix makes it plausible as a business matter, which is not unimportant
author: poniewozik

text: The ideal is day-and-date. Which again is why I'm not wholly on Netflix's side here either. The counterargument to that, as I understand it, is too many people would choose wrongly and thus need their choice limited.
author: poniewozik

text: IOW, I agree that Netflix is in no way acting from principle. That does not mean there is no principle involved.
author: poniewozik

text: But to push back again: the window isn't the ideal form of choice either. It's saying, "I can choose theatrical and you can choose streaming, but I should have access to my choice first." That's just not going to be a widely persuasive argument.
author: poniewozik

text: I suspect the reason is that Netflix, unlike Prime, is in an actual position to supplant theatrical, or at least a substantial chunk of it, so it has a business motive Amazon lacks?
author: poniewozik

text: (I mean, yeah, Trump could be removed from office if a bunch of Republicans turn on him as well--but that then does not require Dems taking any body of Congress.)
author: poniewozik

text: Plus impeachment not = removal from office, which needs 67 Senate votes. Honestly, the followup story I'd be curious to see is WHY WH staff are worried about impeachment, given how well Bill Clinton's approval did after his impeachment and acquittal.
author: poniewozik

text: I thought it would have worked so well as a series finale that I double-checked to make sure it wasn't a limited series before running my review. Not opposed to more, but also *really* don't want it to have to go to lengths to continue the story.

text: "Barry" is an excellent series. I think we can also have an interesting conversation, after the first season finishes (I've seen it all), about whether, artistically, it should only have a season or two more. (Or if it should have been one-and-done.)

text: There we get to the 50% where I agree with Scott: obvs Netflix has an interest in becoming *the* medium for seeing film, or at least the dominant one, which also does not promote maximal choice in the long run.
author: poniewozik

text: If they can only be preserved by denying people a choice they would otherwise make if they could, that's not a strong argument for their preservation. But I will admit I say this as someone who goes to those theaters and doesn't have a better idea for saving them.
author: poniewozik

text: Which is a French attitude about cultural preservation as a whole, and there are arguments for it, but it's the sort of thing on which I'm hopelessly American.
author: poniewozik

text: Can't wait for Paul Ryan's memoir, I DON'T LIKE THAT YOU FEEL THAT WAY
author: poniewozik

text: And I know, I know, people can always choose to see films at home eventually, when the window expires, but that still amounts to a freedom-from-choice argument IMHO--that the audience as a whole needs to be protected from the decisions individuals would make if they could.
author: poniewozik

text: I 50% agree? I don't like Netflix keeping their films out of theaters. But the ideal for me is that the audience have maximal choice. The theatrical experience should be preserved through people wanting to see movies in theaters, not through their having to.

text: Yeah, I would love it if this were taught widely in schools. People scarcely know how TV ads work, and we've had commercial TV for 70 years! People should at least understand that it's not like a penny drops in FB's vault when you look at your cousin's baby photos.
author: poniewozik

text: Maybe I'm being harsh. I know media is tough to pay for! But IMHO any business model that depends on people not really knowing how it works is a business model that should not exist.
